intro: Ocimum campechianum, commonly known as the Mexican basil or wild basil, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Central America. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate leaves that have a fragrant, mint-like aroma. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pink or purple and are arranged in whorled clusters. Ocimum campechianum is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb due to its aromatic properties.
